content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)
    # Split the markdown into lines
    lines = split(md, "\n")

    stack = Stack()
    question_text = ""
    answer_text = ""

    for line in lines
        if starts_with(line, "# Question"))
            push!(stack, "Question")
            question_text = strip(line)[12:]
        elseif starts_with(line, "# Answer"))
            if !isempty(question_text) && !isempty(answer_text)
                (question_text, answer_text)
            else
                error("No matching question found for the answer.")
            end
            push!(stack, "Answer")
            answer_text = strip(line)[12:]
        elseif is_empty(stack) || peek!(stack) == "Question"
            # If at top or in Question section, keep processing lines
            continue
        else
            # In Answer section, ignore non-answer lines
            continue
        end
    end

    if !isempty(question_text) && !isempty(answer_text)
        (question_text, answer_text)
    else
        error("No matching question found for the answer.")
    end
end
```
This function `q_and_a_extractor` takes a markdown-formatted text as input and returns a tuple containing the extracted question and answer. It strips any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

If no matching question is found, it will throw an error.
